channel.title: Getting Started on Oracle Backend for Parse Platform
channel.description: Recent content in Getting Started on Oracle Backend for Parse Platform

item.title: Users, Roles and ACLs
item.description: Users, Roles and ACLs Creating Users You can create a user with this Representational State Transfer (REST) API. You must provide the correct APPLICATION_ID and endpoint for your environment. For example: curl -X POST \ -H "X-Parse-Application-Id: COOLAPPV100" \ -H "X-Parse-Revocable-Session: 1" \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"username":"newuser","password":"newpassword","phone":"415-392-0202"}' \ http://1.2.3.4/parse/users # output (formatted): { "objectId":"DrIxj80hAf", "createdAt":"2022-12-12T18:11:18.497Z", "sessionToken":"r:6cad2f1fcd7de36e68ed86e3d215d324" } NOTE: Email server integration is not available in this Developer Preview.

item.title: Using the Parse Dashboard
item.description: Using the Parse Dashboard The Oracle Backend for Parse Platform includes a web user interface for managing your applications. To learn more, see the dashboard page. Next, go to the Users, Roles and ACLs page to learn more.

item.title: Working with Objects
item.description: The Oracle Backend for Parse Platform stores your data in objects. Each object is an instance of a named class. A class has certain properties or fields. You create a class by creating the first object in that class. You define the fields by using them. Once a class has a field with a certain type, you cannot change that field type while objects using it exist. Creating an Object The most basic operation that you can do is to create a new object in the database.
